head.headtext: Privilege against self-incrimination—Privilege of an accused not to incriminate himself through non-testimonial actions

para.paratext:
There are four requirements for triggering an accused's Fifth Amendment privilege.
“The information sought must be (1) incriminating; (2) personal to the defendant; (3) compelled; and (4) testimonial or communicative in nature.”
[1] The extent to which an accused may incriminate himself through non-testimonial actions is often the subject of debate. Federal practice is more strict in this application of the privilege, while Georgia law is a bit broader. Under former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-20[2] “non-communicative” evidence, which is not protected by the Fifth Amendment, was still deemed privileged.

In early cases, some state courts held that to require an accused to perform any affirmative action on his part would violate this aspect of his privilege. An Alabama court even held that having a criminal defendant stand in the courtroom for identification forced him to give evidence against himself and violated his privilege.[
3 ] Similarly, a Georgia court held that it was erroneous to order a defendant to stand so that a witness could see where his right leg was amputated, since this required him to give evidence against himself.[
4] In Allbright v. State ,[5] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the trial court erroneously admitted photographs of the handcuffed defendants standing beside a distilling apparatus because the photographs were taken without their consent. Currently, Georgia law provides that the state may force a criminally accused to produce incriminating evidence, but may not require him to do anything to produce evidence which would not have existed absent his action.[
6] “The distinction is between forcing an accused to Do an act against his will and requiring an accused to Submit to an act. While the latter ‘takes evidence from the defendant,’ and is constitutionally acceptable, the former compels the defendant, in essence, to give evidence, which violates an individual's right not to incriminate himself.”
[7] The “shoe in the tracks” cases best illustrate this rule. Generally, articles of clothing worn by the accused may be used in evidence against him without violating his privilege against self-incrimination. Therefore, it is acceptable for an officer to take the accused's shoes from him at the scene of the crime and fit them into tracks.[
8] However, requiring the accused to fit his shoe to a track without his consent requires him to perform an affirmative act of self-incrimination and violates his privilege.[
9]

Formerly under this rationale, the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination did not protect an accused from being compelled to provide blood samples or otherwise submit to a blood test.[
10] For instance, in Williams v. State ,[11 ] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that a police officer did not violate accused's constitutional rights when he requested a sample of accused's blood for DNA testing after accused invoked his right to counsel. Blood sampling for a DNA test, although potentially incriminating, was not considered testimonial or communicative in nature.[
12] Similarly, an officer's request that the accused submit to a blood-alcohol test and the accused's refusal was not protected, and such evidence was admissible against him.[
13]

The United States Supreme Court has overruled this line of reasoning, and now the rule is that the right under the Fourth Amendment to be free of unreasonable searches and seizures is also applicable to the compelled withdrawal of blood, since the extraction of blood is a search within the meaning of the constitution. In Missouri v. McNeely, [14] the Supreme Court rejected a per se rule that the natural metabolization of alcohol in a person's blood stream constitutes an exigency justifying a bright line exception to the Fourth Amendment's search warrant requirement for nonconsensual blood testing in all DUI cases. The Georgia Supreme Court adopted this holding in Williams v. State. [15] A breath test is likewise a search within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment, and like a blood test, pursuant to Williams, there is no per se rule automatically equating an affirmative response to the implied consent notice with actual consent to search within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment.[
16] Courts must now conduct a case-by-case analysis considering the totality of the circumstances.

Compelling accused to submit to a gun powder residue test does not violate the privilege. In English v. State ,[17] a nitric acid test was performed on the accused's hands to see if he had fired a gun. He contended that his privilege against self-incrimination was violated since he was directed to turn his hands for the swabbing. The Georgia Supreme Court held that the removal of substances from his hands was non-testimonial and did not violate his privilege.[
18]

Courts have upheld the following as non-testimonial, non-communicative forms of evidence whose collection does not violate the accused's constitutional rights: hair samples,[19] verbalizing specific words in a lineup,[20] standing before the jury before a video of the drug transaction was played,[21] stripping to his waist and being photographed,[22] and displaying a body part or a scar for a photograph which may be admitted against him at trial.[
23]

In Lawson v. State ,[24] two victims were robbed, at different times, by black men dressed as females. The two defendants were spotted, dressed as females, in an automobile that had been described by an informant. They were photographed in their female disguise before a warrant was obtained, and these photographs were held to be admissible over a claim of the privilege against self-incrimination.

The Georgia Court of Appeals has also held that, while a defendant has a right to be present at his trial, which he can waive, he does not have a concomitant right to be absent from the trial. The trial court is empowered to order a criminal defendant's personal appearance when it is necessary to properly conduct the trial, and the defendant's mere presence in the courtroom does not violate his privilege against self-incrimination.[
25] For example, the court can order defendant's personal appearance at trial for the purpose of being identified by witnesses.[
26] In Lewis v. State, [27] the trial court properly refused to honor defendant's request to leave the courtroom.

In Andresen v. Maryland ,[28] the United States Supreme Court carried the testimonial test further by holding that seizing defendant's business records pursuant to a search warrant did not violate his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination because the defendant had not been required to produce the documents nor would he be compelled to authenticate them. Some of the documents contained incriminating statements made by the defendant. The Court quoted Mr. Justice Holmes from Johnson v. U.S. [29] as follows: “‘A party is privileged from producing the evidence but not from its production.’ … [ T]he protection afforded by the Self-Incrimination Clause of the Fifth Amendment ‘adheres basically to the person, not to information that may incriminate him.’
”[30]

The United States Supreme Court considered business records again in U.S. v. Doe[31 ] where a grand jury placed the business records of a sole proprietorship under subpoena and the lower courts had granted a motion to quash the subpoena. The Court reversed in part, holding that the Fifth Amendment privilege does not protect an individual's tax records or business records in his possession. Citing Fisher v. U.S. ,[32] the Court noted that, “[w]here the preparation of business records is voluntary, no compulsion is present.”
[33] Thus, “[a] subpoena that demands production of documents does not compel oral testimony; nor would it ordinarily compel the [defendant] to restate, repeat, or affirm the truth of the contents of the documents sought.”
[34] However, a problem arises if the act of producing the documents actually establishes the authenticity or custody of the documents and thereby incriminates the accused. In such cases, the accused must be granted use immunity for the act of production to avoid any Fifth Amendment violation.[
35]

States are not limited by the federal view of the Fifth Amendment, but may grant a broader privilege. Georgia has done this through O.C.G.A. § 24-5-506 and the Georgia Constitution. This is illustrated in Georgia's approach to the admissibility of handwriting exemplars. In Gilbert v. California ,[36] the United States Supreme Court held that compelled production of a handwriting exemplar, which contains no communicative or testimonial information, does not violate an accused's Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination because an accused's handwriting, like his voice or body, is an identifying physical characteristic outside constitutional protection. However, under the Georgia Constitution a defendant cannot be compelled to produce a handwriting exemplar[37] and one is only admissible if it was a voluntary writing by the accused.[
38]

In Thomas v. State ,[39] the Georgia Supreme Court held that the routine collection of a suspect's signature on a fingerprint card during booking into jail, even in the absence of Miranda warnings, does not constitute compelled self-incrimination in violation of the state constitution and the signature may be used as evidence against him at trial.

Georgia's privilege is also distinguishable from federal practice with respect to the admissibility of intoximeter results. In
Purvis v. State ,[40] the Georgia Supreme Court noted that an intoximeter test does not pose a problem of self-incrimination under the United States Constitution because the Fifth Amendment does not apply to such non-communicative acts.

In addition, neither the statute prohibiting compelled self-incrimination, nor the state constitution requires law enforcement to warn suspects in custody of their right to refuse to perform an incriminating act, and thus Miranda warnings are not required before a field sobriety test if the suspect is in custody.[
41] Similarly, in Scanlon v. State ,[42] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that an officer did not need to issue a Miranda warning before asking that an accused in custody submit to a chemical breath test.[
43]

In Olevik v. State, [44] the Georgia Supreme Court held that the Georgia Constitution's right against compelled self-incrimination[45] prevents the state from forcing someone to submit to a chemical breath test. The Court declined an invitation to overrule Olevik in Elliot v. State [46] and further concluded that the state constitutional right also prohibits admission in evidence of a defendant's refusal of a breath test.

Under the new Code, O.C.G.A. § 24-5-506, which in part provides: “No person who is charged in any criminal proceeding with the commission of any criminal offense shall be compellable to give evidence for or against himself or herself.”
Smith v. State, 247 Ala. 354, 24 So. 2d 546 (1946) .
Blackwell v. State, 67 Ga. 76, 1881 WL 3334 (1881).

But see Butler v. State, 277 Ga. App. 57, 625 S.E.2d 458 (2005), where it was held that an accused may properly be required to stand up so the jurors can see him before they view a video of a drug buy.
Allbright v. State, 92 Ga. App. 251, 88 S.E.2d 468 (1955).

See Creamer v. State, 229 Ga. 511, 192 S.E.2d 350 (1972), holding that although evidence may be compulsorily adduced from an accused, it is constitutionally impermissible to compel an accused to perform an act which results in the production of incriminating evidence.
State v. Armstead, 152 Ga. App. 56, 56, 262 S.E.2d 233 (1979) (citing Creamer v. State, 229 Ga. 511, 192 S.E.2d 350 (1972) (emphasis added)).

Day v. State, 63 Ga. 667, 1879 WL 2623 (1879); Elder v. State, 143 Ga. 363, 85 S.E. 97 (1915), followed in State v. Thornton, 253 Ga. 524, 322 S.E.2d 711 (1984) (overruled on other grounds by, Neal v. State, 290 Ga. 563, 722 S.E.2d 765 (2012)).
Schmerber v. California, 384 U.S. 757, 86 S. Ct. 1826, 16 L. Ed. 2d 908 (1966); Williams v. State, 257 Ga. App. 54, 570 S.E.2d 362 (2002).

See also Raines v. White, 248 Ga. 406, 284 S.E.2d 7 (1981) , which held that requiring defendant to submit to blood test for purpose of proving or disproving paternity would not unconstitutionally compel him to be witness against himself within meaning of Fifth Amendment of United States Constitution nor compel him to give testimony tending in any manner to incriminate himself within meaning of state constitution.
Welch v. State, 254 Ga. 603, 331 S.E.2d 573 (1985), followed the Raines case as to a blood sample for identification.
Welch v. State was followed in Carey v. State, 257 Ga. 134, 356 S.E.2d 507 (1987).

In Long v. State, 176 Ga. App. 898, 335 S. E. 2d 587 (1985), the defendant was unconscious when the blood sample was taken. The trial judge had properly denied a motion to suppress.
Long v. State was followed in Bartell v. State, 181 Ga. App. 148, 351 S.E.2d 495 (1986).

In Robinson v. State, 180 Ga. App. 43, 50, 348 S.E.2d 662 (1986), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 256 Ga. 564, 350 S.E.2d 464 (1986), blood and urine samples were taken from the defendant under a search warrant. His right against self-incrimination was not violated.

In Williams v. State, 257 Ga. App. 54, 570 S.E.2d 362 (2002), the Court of Appeals, relying on Schmerber v. California, supra, found that seeking the defendant's consent to the blood test did not require advice of counsel. Since the defendant did not have the privilege against self-incrimination, he could not assert the right to counsel. The police could have drawn the sample even without consent, so seeking the consent without counsel did not violate his right to counsel.

In Quarterman v. State, 282 Ga. 383, 651 S.E.2d 32 (2007), the Georgia Supreme Court found that former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-60 (now O.C.G.A. § 35-3-160), which requires persons who have been convicted of felonies and are incarcerated in state correctional facilities to submit DNA samples does not violate the United States Constitution or the Georgia Constitution.
Williams v. State, 257 Ga. App. 54, 570 S.E.2d 362 (2002).

The state's maintenance (in a DNA database) of a profile generated from a seminal fluid stain at the scene of an alleged rape also does not violate a defendant's rights against self incrimination with respect to later offenses for which defendant was implicated in part through the use of information in the DNA database.
Fortune v. State, 300 Ga. App. 550, 685 S.E.2d 466 (2009).
See Williams v. State, 257 Ga. App. 54, 570 S.E.2d 362 (2002).
Lankford v. State, 204 Ga. App. 405, 419 S.E.2d 498 (1992).

See also South Dakota v. Neville, 459 U.S. 553, 103 S. Ct. 916, 74 L. Ed. 2d 748 (1983), where the Supreme Court held that the admission of the refusal of the accused to submit to a blood alcohol test did not violate his privilege against self-incrimination.
South Dakota v. Neville was followed in Wessels v. State, 169 Ga. App. 246, 312 S.E.2d 361 (1983) .
Missouri v. McNeely, 133 S. Ct. 1552, 185 L. Ed. 2d 696 (2013). See also Birchfield v. North Dakota, 136 S. Ct. 614, 193 L. Ed. 2d 494 (2015).
Williams v. State, 296 Ga. 817, 771 S.E.2d 373 (2015).
Kendrick v. State, 335 Ga. App. 766, 782 S.E.2d 842 (2016).
English v. State, 234 Ga. 602, 216 S.E.2d 851 (1975).
English v. State, 234 Ga. 602, 216 S.E.2d 851 (1975).

See also Strickland v. State, 247 Ga. 219, 275 S.E.2d 29 (1981) (holding that swabbing the hands of the defendant for a ballistics test did not violate the privilege); Tuff v. State, 278 Ga. 91, 597 S.E.2d 328 (2004).
Tiller v. State, 238 Ga. 67, 230 S.E.2d 874 (1976).
Tate v. State, 153 Ga. App. 508, 265 S.E.2d 818 (1980).
Butler v. State, 277 Ga. App. 57, 625 S.E.2d 458 (2005).
Ingram v. State, 253 Ga. 622, 634, 323 S.E.2d 801 (1984) (internal cite omitted).
See also Scott v. State, 274 Ga. 476, 554 S.E.2d 488 (2001) (a photo to be taken of his tattoo).

Rivers v. State, 265 Ga. 694, 461 S.E.2d 205 (1995) (photograph of right hand did not violate privilege); Scott v. State, 274 Ga. 476, 478, 554 S.E.2d 488 (2001) (photograph of scar did not violate privilege).
Lewis v. State, 164 Ga. App. 549, 297 S.E.2d 303 (1982).
Lewis v. State, 164 Ga. App. 549, 297 S.E.2d 303 (1982); Graham v. State, 171 Ga. App. 242, 319 S.E.2d 484 (1984).
Lewis v. State, 164 Ga. App. 549, 297 S.E.2d 303 (1982).
Andresen v. Maryland, 427 U.S. 463, 96 S. Ct. 2737, 49 L. Ed. 2d 627 (1976).
Andresen v. Maryland, 427 U.S. 463, 473, 96 S. Ct. 2737, 49 L. Ed. 2d 627 (1976).
Gilbert v. California, 388 U.S. 263, 87 S. Ct. 1951, 18 L. Ed. 2d 1178 (1967).
Ward v. State, 262 Ga. 293, 417 S.E.2d 130 (1992) (citing State v. Armstead, 152 Ga. App. 56, 262 S.E.2d 233 (1979)); Thomas v. State, 274 Ga. 156, 549 S.E.2d 359 (2001) .
Purvis v. State, 129 Ga. App. 208, 199 S.E.2d 366 (1973) (relying on Schmerber v. California, 384 U.S. 757, 86 S. Ct. 1826, 16 L. Ed. 2d 908 (1966)).

State v. Turnquest, 305 Ga. 758, 827 S.E.2d 865 (2019) (while the Georgia Constitution prohibits the compulsion of incriminating acts and testimony, and the Georgia statute prohibits compelled self-incrimination, nothing requires law enforcement to provide Miranda-like warnings to persons arrested for DUI before asking them to submit to a breath test).
Scanlon v. State, 237 Ga. App. 362, 514 S.E.2d 876 (1999).

Ga. Proc., Criminal Procedure § 26:6, Procurement of natural body substances (2008). But see Cooper v. State, 277 Ga. 282, 587 S.E.2d 605 (2003) (overruled on other grounds by, Olevik v. State, 302 Ga. 228, 806 S.E.2d 505 (2017)) (holding that compelled chemical testing constituted an unreasonable search and seizure).
Ga. Const. Art. I, para. XVI.
Elliott v. State, 305 Ga. 179, 824 S.E.2d 265 (2019) .
